reviewText: Memento Mori is a heavily story-driven point'n click game with beautiful graphics and great musical score. The plot twists and turns nicely during the game. Unfortunately the puzzle design isn't very original and most of the puzzles aren't very challenging, although moving the puzzle solving to 3D does make some of the problems seem new and refreshing. The voice acting is occasionally very annoying but you get used to it. Overall Memento Mori is a good purchase for an adventure gamer Both its story and the shocking finale linger on the edge of thoughts for a long time after playing through the game. This is the way to end a game.
voteText: 50 of 57 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText: If there is one thing that impressed me in this game, it's the fact that there are animations to every action and all of them fit perfectly with the surroundings. In most of games, there are generic animations to take or put an object, but not in this one. That's a huge work the devs have done. This really is a good game, with many endings, even if the story is a bit special (but i won't spoil).

reviewText: I really enjoyed this game. And at a cost of less than £1 it was an absolute bargain. reviewText:
I decided to go 'negative' for my review on this game mostly because of its price. I enjoyed it but the number of flaws it has makes £9.99 too expensive. If I had to rate it I would give it 5/10. If you want to buy it, wait for a sale and I'd recommend you spend a maximum of £5 for it.

The most enjoyable bit of this game is its plot. It's nicely detailed, intriguing and unpredictable. The puzzles are mostly logical and enjoyable too.

The reason I give this game a mediocre score is that everything else is lack-lustre. The visuals are adequate, the background music ia a bit poor and the voice acting highly variable.The interface takes a little while to get used to. You have an iicon that appears over a useable object that should display what right click and left click will do but this icon is really hard to see.

The worst thing about the game is the script writing and characterisation. With the exception of Lara (one of the two player characters), everyone in the game seems pretty unpleasant. Conversations feel forced and too drawn out. Sometimes it is even difficult to figure out what a character is trying to say because the wording is so weird and unnatural.

If you like story-rich point and clicks, wait for a sale and get this. Otherwise don't bother.

reviewText: Stilted dialog, pixel-hunting, and counter-intuitive puzzles make this an example of what's wrong with modern-day point-and-clicks.  None of this is as bad as the awful dialog system, however, in which you are typically presented with 3 different responses: positive, negative, and curious.  The problem is that the game doesn't bother to tell you the specifics of what your character will say when you pick one of these--you just have to pick the attitude that most closely matches what you WANT to say and hope that that's what the game designers had in mind as well.  The story probably would have been interesting if not for the badly written and poorly voice-acted dialog.  Can't recommend this one.

reviewText: While the plot may be engaging, the gameplay seems to mainly consists of chasing down artifical progress blockers like replacement phone batteries, lighters, and cell phone reception. reviewText:
I really, really wanted to like this game. I've been a fan of adventure point and click games since their heyday in the 90s. It does have some good elements and some that are lacking. For the short version; if it's on sale and you need something to do for the next 10 hours, get it. If you're expecting a great adventure game on the scale of Longest Journey or Syberia, you're in for a big letdown. I'm only going to select the yes" for recommending this game because I don't want this genre to die. I want more developers to create more adventure games!

Pros:
****The characters' voices all have appropriate regional accents. The French character of Max has a French accent and the Russian character of Lara has a charming Russian accent. Points for authenticity!
****Like most adventure games
date: there are puzzles and they all fit into the context of the game and had logical answers. Some may have been a little too easy while others required a bit too much pixel hunting. All in all though
recommended: the puzzles were good.\n****Nice graphics and scenery design. I'm a digital artist so I always appreciate great graphics and well rendered 3D models. Some character animations were used time and again but I came to see them as just character quirks rather than the developer recycling animations.\n****The game took about 10 hours for me to complete and I only had to check a walk-through once because I missed clicking on something in a scene. Since I bought this game when is was about $3
hoursPlayed:
I'd say I made a fantastic investment.

Cons
****The story doesn't really make any sense and by the time you get to the ending you will have a feeling of  WTF?! Even though they had the character explain the entire story and why everything happened at the end of the game (it was a worse "entire plot explanation" than you'd find in one of the old Sean Connery James Bond movies)
voteText: it still made no sense to me at all. You know what people say about the ending of Lost? This ending tops that. I understand what they were saying but
votesHelpful:
it makes no sense to me.
****The "multiple endings" thing is a joke. If you don't do something in a few scenes then you get a different voice-over epilogue. That's it. I was quite disappointed by that. I love games were my choices matter but this had nothing to do with choice and everything to do with just crossing all the T's and dotting the I's.

So yeah
votesTotal: technically good but story-wise it's confusing and forgettable. Like I said
votesFunny: if it goes on sale again at a cheap price then pick it up for a great time-killer. If you're expecting a great adventure game where your choices actually matter and there is a fantastic story

reviewText:
Memento Mori delivers very little excitement, interest, or fun.

Pros: Story, Controls
Cons: Graphics, Gameplay, Bugs

Memento Mori follows Max Durand's search for a stolen painting to save his reputation.  The story is okay but below the average mystery/drama show.  Controls are fine for a point-and-click, nothing fancy or groundbreaking.

Unfortunately, the graphics are subpar, even for a 2008 release.  The gameplay is standard for the genre, but rather boring and frivolous: fetch a pen from your home because your workplace (Interpol) has none, or deliver a coffee that's on the counter to someone yelling for coffee in the next room.

Memento Mori is simply outshined by TV shows of the same genre, the latter offering better dialogue, visuals, and zero meaningless gameplay between scenes.

5/10

reviewText:
Excellent point and click adventure game for me, visuals are nice, models and animation is pretty good (FMV sequences not so much), good voice and locations, characters are solid.

The story is intriguing and has a strangeish mix of real-life and supernatural entwined, with a twist at the end that didn't hit me as hard as it perhaps should have but may impress others more so.

The puzzles overall are mostly logical and have a unique mechanic by allowing you to rotate around objects to find clues, information or switches which adds a nice element the 2d counterparts don't or aren't able to showcase.

There are however 2 to 3 dodgy puzzles. I had to go on the internet twice, once for some dialogue refresh to remember what I was trying to do next and then for the symbol puzzle towards the end which I don't think was done as well as the others in terms of figuring it out for yourself.

I'd say a very solid 8.5/10
